I <FI>am<Fi> the rose of Sharon, <FI>and<Fi> the lily of the valleys.
As the lily among thorns, so <FI>is<Fi> my love among the daughters.<CM>

As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so <FI>is<Fi> my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit <FI>was<Fi> sweet to my taste.<RF>I sat…: Heb. I delighted and sat down, etc<Rf><RF>taste: Heb. palate<Rf>
He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me <FI>was<Fi> love.<RF>banqueting…: Heb. house of wine<Rf>
Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I <FI>am<Fi> sick of love.<RF>comfort…: Heb. straw me with apples<Rf>
His left hand <FI>is<Fi> under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.
I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake <FI>my<Fi> love, till he please.<RF>I charge…: Heb. I adjure you<Rf><CM>
The voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
My beloved is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.<RF>shewing…: Heb. flourishing<Rf>
My beloved spake, and said unto me, Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over <FI>and<Fi> gone;
The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing <FI>of birds<Fi> is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
The fig tree putteth forth her green figs, and the vines <FI>with<Fi> the tender grape give a <FI>good<Fi> smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.<CM>

O my dove, <FI>that art<Fi> in the clefts of the rock, in the secret <FI>places<Fi> of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet <FI>is<Fi> thy voice, and thy countenance <FI>is<Fi> comely.
Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines: for our vines <FI>have<Fi> tender grapes.
My beloved <FI>is<Fi> mine, and I <FI>am<Fi> his: he feedeth among the lilies.
Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.<RF>of Bether: or, of division<Rf><CM>
